questions.answer_description:
Step 1: Verify that the certificate is valid or not. In case of any warning message, cancel the download.
Step 2: If certificate issue is not there then, download the file in your system.
Step 3: Calculate the hash value of the downloaded file.
Step 4: Match the hash value of the downloaded file with the one which you selected on the website.
Step 5: Install the file if the hash value matches.

discussion.content:
To obtain a file's hash value do: 
in cmd:
certutil -hashfile <file> SHA512 
In powershell
Get-FileHash <file> -Algorithm SHA256 | formar-list
Do can I do this without the path switch if I am in the same dir?
Exam tip. choose a mirror with https.

comments.content: Are you referring to the very first line? Could you elaborate and/or provide a source that supports this?

discussion.content:
B-
gets
The stdio gets() function does not check for buffer length and always results in a vulnerability.

choices.D: Format string vulnerability is present for admin users but not for standard users.
choices.C: Hardcoded usernames with different code paths taken depend on which user is entered.
choices.A: Only short usernames are supported, which could result in brute forcing of credentials.
choices.B: Buffer overflow in the username parameter could lead to a memory corruption vulnerability.

discussion.content: OLA's are typically paired with an SLA to support it. OLA's define a company's internal dependent unit responsibilities & delivery timelines.

questions.question_text: To meet an SLA, which of the following document should be drafted, defining the company's internal interdependent unit responsibilities and delivery timelines.
questions.answer_description: OLA is an agreement between the internal support groups of an institution that supports SLA. According to the Operational Level Agreement, each internal support group has certain responsibilities to the other group. The OLA clearly depicts the performance and relationship of the internal service groups. The main objective of OLA is to ensure that all the support groups provide the intended ServiceLevelAgreement.

comments.content:
I am not entirely sure, but you may be right. The following is from the OWASP website:

Replacive Fuzzing

Replacive fuzzing can be defined as the process of fuzzing part of a request by means of replacing it with a set value. This value is known as a fuzz vector. In the case of:

http://www.example.com/8302fa3b

Testing against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) by sending the following fuzz vectors:

http://www.example.com/>"><script>alert("XSS")</script>&

http://www.example.com/'';!--"<XSS>=&{()}

This is a form of replacive fuzzing. In this category, the total number of requests is dependent on the number of fuzz vectors specified.

The remainder of this appendix presents a number of fuzz vector categories.
https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/v41/6-Appendix/C-Fuzz_Vectors

discussion.content:
LOL EVERYONE IS WRONG

It's fuzzing, as you have SQL injection, XSS and directory traversal attempts.
the random letters in the username block are to distract from the script to the right. I think it's SQL injection.
D - multiple things are going on here so it can only be Brute forcing that makes sense.

comments.content: Isn't brute force only in terms of passwords? I've never heard/seen it used to mean trying lots of different things that don't involve passwords.

discussion.content:
A. SQL injection
Not a brute force b/c that deals with passwords or passphrases and not username or comment input. Also, 1=1 is inputting a true statement into the DB to dump the DB to the attacker.

comments.content: No, brute force includes usernames as well. There is only one instance of 1=1, and it by itself is not an sql injection. Correct answer here is brute force, as the attacker is trying several usernames and inputs to try and get a successful result.

Now I am leaning back towards SQL Injection. The user name probably does not matter.
Most of the stuff in the comments section would not create a successful SQL injection. With the possible exception of a <script>. I am guessing a lot of it is just red herrings. You are right about 1=1 by itself not being a useful SQL injection. But, the attacker is trying to inject something into the database, not guess at a password, or passphrase.

But I will say this is tricky because the username here might not matter. But the fact that the attacker is trying other inputs, such as the wget command or <script>, tells me that it is a brute force attempt of different input to get his desired results.

discussion.content:
Maybe: D. Brute forcing ?
I see the 1=1. But considering the number of entries, could this be a type of brute force attack?

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A. Read the row for data security controls.

A has two option from the data security row (context-based awareness and FDE for the database server).
B has one (FDE).
C has zero.
D has one (context-based awareness).
statement key is confidentiality, so the answer is A

comments.content:
The statement is asking, wich combination meet the minimum control set and cover the confidentiality of the database?
Lets try:
D. Intrusion detection capabilities, network-based IPS, generator, and context-based authentication.D only see access controls but not confidentiality., so D is not.
C. Peer review of all application changes, static analysis of application code, UPS, and penetration testing of the complete system. C. Does not see any requeriment and just for test the securities capabilities, but the statement does not say anything about. So C is not.
B. Cipher lock on the server room door, FDE, surge protector, and static analysis of all application code. B just protect the server room but does not talk about confidentiality. So B is not.
A. Proximity card access to the server room, context-based authentication, UPS, and full-disk encryption for the database server. A. protects the server room, and is clear near to the matrix and cover the keywords confidentiality with data base encryption. Based on CASP+ Risk Mitigation Strategies chapter.
Answer A - has no logical security and no application security at all. Either of those could compromise confidentiality.

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. Cipher lock on the server room door, FDE, surge protector, and static analysis of all application code?
Surge protector is minimum security. But we are only looking at confidentiality, not data integrity, or availability. No logical protection at all. Fails on, at least, one count. Since all the others fail on, at least, two counts; I suppose this is the best answer.
Answer 'A' has no logical security at all.

comments.content: Answer 'A' also has no application security at all.
if you're so sure, go into detail, stop just saying it isn't the answer.
Oops. I think this should be C, not D.

D. Peer review of all application changes, static analysis of application code, UPS, and penetration testing of the complete system.

Again, no logical protection. Also no physical security. Fails on, at least, two counts.

B. Intrusion detection capabilities, network-based IPS, generator, and context-based authentication.

Context-based authentication is minimum protection. Intrusion detection capabilities is not listed. No application security. This is the only one with any logical protection. Fails on, at least, two counts.
Oops. I think this should be B, not C.

How much detail do you need?
Logical security: HIDS, NIDS, NIPS: A has none of those.
Application security: Peer Review, Static Analysis, Penetration testing: A has none of those. 
Answer A completely fails on two counts.
A has no logical security or application security. Fails on two counts.

discussion.content:
A.
Don't get fooled when you see "context-based authentication" because it's a minimum control set. In the same category the answer lists full-disk encryption (FDE) which is under the same control set, but at a higher category.

a. 
It meets or exceeds the requirements of the matrix, therefore is acceptable.

comments.content: Answer A has logical security, or application security. Total fail on two counts.

choices.D: Intrusion detection capabilities, network-based IPS, generator, and context-based authentication.
choices.C: Peer review of all application changes, static analysis of application code, UPS, and penetration testing of the complete system.
choices.B: Cipher lock on the server room door, FDE, surge protector, and static analysis of all application code.
choices.A: Proximity card access to the server room, context-based authentication, UPS, and full-disk encryption for the database server.

questions.question_text:
An organization has established the following controls matrix:
//IMG//

The following control sets have been defined by the organization and are applied in aggregate fashion:
✑ Systems containing PII are protected with the minimum control set.
✑ Systems containing medical data are protected at the moderate level.
✑ Systems containing cardholder data are protected at the high level.
The organization is preparing to deploy a system that protects the confidentially of a database containing PII and medical data from clients. Based on the controls classification, which of the following controls would BEST meet these requirements?
